title: 114_hr3869
content: The Act titled "State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015" focuses on coordinating cybersecurity efforts between state and local governments with the National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to enhance coordination between the National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center and state/local governments in identifying and addressing cybersecurity vulnerabilities and risks. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 aims to improve coordination between the National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center and state/local governments to address cybersecurity vulnerabilities. It involves providing tools, resources, and guidelines for information security and collaborating with senior government officials. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 aims to coordinate with State and local officials to ensure effective implementation of information security tools and provide cybersecurity training to address risks and incidents. Additionally, privacy and civil liberties training will be provided in collaboration with the Chief Privacy Officer and Chief Civil Rights and Civil Liberties Officer of the Department. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 aims to provide cybersecurity training and technical assistance to State and local governments for implementing information security tools. This includes deploying technology for cyber threat mitigation, analyzing data on information security, and conducting operational evaluations. The State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 provides cybersecurity training and technical assistance to State and local governments. This includes conducting threat and vulnerability assessments on information systems, assisting in coordinating vulnerability disclosures, and ensuring awareness of information security tools and resources developed by the Department and other Federal agencies. The Privacy and civil liberties training provided under the State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 includes processes, methods, and information consistent with the Department's Fair Information Practice Principles. It aims to limit the receipt, retention, use, and disclosure of information related to cybersecurity risks and incidents associated with specific persons. The Privacy and civil liberties training provided under the State and Local Cyber Protection Act of 2015 aims to protect information systems from cybersecurity risks, minimize impact on privacy and civil liberties, ensure data integrity by removing obsolete personal information, and safeguard cyber threat indicators and defensive measures. The national cybersecurity and communications integration center of the Department of Homeland Security must protect proprietary threat indicators and defensive measures, ensure confidentiality, and comply with constitutional, legal, and privacy protections. Congressional oversight is required within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The House of Representatives and the Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs are required to provide information on the effectiveness of activities related to the national cybersecurity and communications integration center. Feedback from State and local governments on the effectiveness of these activities must be included. The House of Representatives and the Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs are required to provide information on the effectiveness of activities related to the national cybersecurity and communications integration center. This subsection outlines the information that must be provided, with the House of Representatives passing it on December 10, 2015.
